The crew has its sceptics, even though the exorcism seems at first to have worked. Two days later a sailor cries, 'It had glowing yellow eyes!' upon having sighted the demon near the hold. The unholy thing must be caught.
Bait the thing with food

It is nothing so savage. All are concealed around the strip of meat, expecting the worst. But what descends from the rafters of the hold, silent and gentle winged, is a luminous white owl. It is an ambiguous omen, according to those that know, but the sailors are content to keep it aboard.

Whatever it is, it is far too clever. It avoids the bait, but continues its night raids. Rumour this is an offended Klabautermann are substantiated by several separate accounts. Little voices overheard, brief sightings, even the discovery of a miniature table and chair. Some can live with the impish nuisance, but many will jump ship at the next port..
Build a trap to catch the thing

The cage-trap is well-made, and daybreak reveals an unlikely specimen encaged. 'A sort of badger?' is the first analysis, which in actuality, is fairly far from the mark. The compendium of animalia in the ship's library reveals it a 'northern raccoon', also remarking that is 'quite edible.'

The snapping trap is weak and flimsy. The crew are excited by a sharp sound, but rush to the scene, only to find the bait gone, and the trap in disrepair. A piece of bright red felt caught in the spring explains all. 'Klabautermann!' they despair, for it is a terrible omen to offend a sea goblin as they have done.

The crew don't have much belief, and the priest makes a hash of the exorcism. If anything, his fragmented delivery only agitates the creature. The next night, a sailor is adamant he has sighted something 'irrefutably demonic.'
Gather arms and confront it

Rather excessive. The soldiery tense as strange noises draw near. Fingers itch upon triggers. The moment demon wings flap into view, the night is lit up with powder. Finally the smoke subsides, and the mangled thing is revealed to be nothing more than a bat. Troops thunder heavily about the ship, before discovering the rest of the hog-nosed critters in the hold. Everyone is left feeling utterly stupid.

Your lily-livered cowards quiver like jelly! Fear chokes them as they spin wildly about looking for something to shoot that they can't see. Two are so panicked they bump together, causing the other to suddenly fire. Shot hits an angelic young sailor, killing instantly. The night terror is gone, but has taken for payment the most undeserving of souls.
Sate the demon with a sacrificial offering

A man's finger for a stowaway weasel! In good faith, a pious sailor volunteers the pinkie of his right hand as a votive offering. But at the smell of blood, it is a slinky little mustelid that appears. With the weasel caught and caged, the night terror is over, but the sailors will not forgive or forget the loss of a good man's finger.

Sacrilege! A prohibited tome is consulted, the vile solicitations of its pages consuming the crew! Unspeakable acts are performed upon a man, so that the demon can be assuaged. Yet still the menace remains, and worse, the crew's sacrificial victim bleeds out from his injuries.
Don't anger the creature further

The practical joke is ruined. The bored sailors bemoan the pathetic response to their little entertainment. That the senior officers have been duped by an obvious ruse, makes all severely doubt their fitness to lead.

The faithless crew never take any part of the exorcism seriously. 'What's the point of hocus-pocus when its but greedy sailors stealing?!' yells one man. Accusations fly between conspiracy theorists, until a violent brawl breaks out. At the next mooring, the injured parties desert your godless expedition.
Find the culprit

Your sharp-nosed hunters pick up a scent. Pungent droppings demarcate a perimeter, in the centre of which is a crate with a hole. A sailor reaches his arm bravely in. There is a brief struggle, and a whine like the ones at night, before the troublemaker is pulled out. It is a common garden fox. The cunning little creature becomes the crew's talisman for the remainder of the expedition.

Hunters find tracks, but can't say what made them. The marks are indeed strange - disturbing almost. Claw marks that go deep in the decking, as if the unspeakable thing that made them was in some frenzy.
Smoke it out of hiding

Reassuringly human coughing comes from within. It turns out you have a stowaway - a young girl wishing to escape a life of hardship. She is spirited., and the crew take to her quickly. She is given work to do, and food to eat. All believe she shall prove their good luck charm.
Build a trap to catch whatever it is

Knowing its habits helps. The box is made to measure, and along with its clever latch, is placed where the fiend seems most often to be. The box is found in the morning, with a gigantic rat inside it. The trap appears to have killed it, and that is the end of the matter.

The ramshackle trap box is in bits the next morning. While to some they appear benign, the claw marks appear more frequently. Once a man wakes with his cheeks gouged. Some are so perturbed by the night demon, that they slink off the ship at the next available harbour.
Pray together against the spirit

A feeling of calm descends upon the crew. The prayer seems to fill the spiritual void in the sailor's breasts. Approaching the world with a new perspective means even if the unexplained episodes at night persist, they pay it no mind.

The communal prayer is broken by more wild shrieking. It matters not that, apart from vanishing supplies, the mischievous spirit seems fairly harmless. The crew are deeply troubled, and worry their souls are lost.

The hunters stumble guilelessly into its trap. The night is unfeasibly pitch, and the hunters' lamps extinguish. Who knows why, without a breath of wind? A scratching draws near. Then a commotion... and screaming, followed by silence. Just like that, the fiend has gone forever, returning to the air whence it came. Three men lie dead in their own blood. Their livers have been removed.
Ignore the menace
The menace is very persistent. Restless nights, devoured food, and stolen supplies shall go unexplained and unresolved for the remainder of the expedition. The crew are at their wit's end.
Baptism of Fire

Everything points towards the foreboding gate. Salvation lies beyond, but the eerie blue flame that suffuses it keep the crew at a distance. Perhaps it would be safer to find a way through the surrounding jungle, but those of faith say the gate is 'an auspicious sign'.
Have the scientist look at the gate
Have faith and leap through the flames.
Wrap up before leaping through the flames.
Cut through the jungle instead

The scientist banishes the illusion. 'This fire that you perceive around the gate, is simply the agglomeration of azure glow-worms.' Laughter becomes delight, as the party take the pulsing creatures in hand. This is the wonder of nature.

If anything the flames are cool, almost like bundles of ribbons brushing the skin. This gate is, without question, an earthly manifestation of the divine. Ahead, an extremely hospitable settlement affirms the holy blessing.

The doubtful crew are surprised. Drawing closer to the gate, they find the flames seem to give off no heat. One leap of faith and they are through! Still they hesitate, for a perfect skeleton sits propped against it.

Fire and brimstone! The heat is intense, but your procession of false prophets seem numb to the pain. The others watch horrified, as fabric, skin and flesh renders before their eyes. If the expedition continues, it will only be for the mercy of god.
Determine how the person died
Order them to charge through!

The doctor forms a reasonable hypothesis, but cannot be absolutely sure from bone alone. 'The way they sit suggests they lacked the will to continue.' Not wishing to end the same way, the crew are astonished to discover that leaping through the gate does them no harm.

The doctor's career is over. As are the careers of those who heed his words. 'Came through from the other side, but it was not the fire that took him'. As they jump, flames grasp their ankles, and rapidly shoot up and over the rest.
'Ouch!' The men yelp, rolling in the dirt until they are sure they are no longer afire. The strange arch behind them, your brave soldiers compare their battle scars.
'Cowards!' Your men lack the military discipline to follow a simple order! You will have to find another way.
They make it. Rolled-up like carpets they skip through the flaming gate. Their worst complaint is the sweet and overwhelming pong of sweat that now follows them.
'That they died as sausages! or what shall we tell their families!?' Perhaps dousing their mantles in a protective layer of paraffin was a mistake! Your expedition continues to turn on its spit.
The crew have no regrets in plotting such a rational course. Sweaty jungles are the devil they know, crawling with tentacle limb and spider fang. But who knew what sorcery governed that strange gate?
The jungle thins out to a precipice. A long and shoddy-looking bridge stretches to the other side, or else you could attempt to find a way around.

No way through, thanks to your shambolic mapreading. The group becomes separated, and eventually lost. Hacking those ancient and contorted roots has saved no time that couldn't be saved by backtrack, and cost you several lives into the bargain.
Inspect the bridge
Circumnavigate the cliff
It is in passable condition. There are a few nerve-wracking moments, as the wind whips the bridge into a vigorous sway, and all are rather pleased to reach the other side. Your expedition continues.

Most treacherous! The confidence of your craftsmen in the rickety structure couldn't be more misplaced. Of course it is nothing if not dramatic, when the bridge cables twang, and one after the other pile into the gorge.
It is a long trek, that could have been much longer but for the competence of those with a compass. Yet another hiccup for the expedition log book.
Imbecile orienteers! There is no other way across this river valley for a hundred miles! You have covered half that distance before you realise, wasting a lot of time and provisions.
Love Island

A matter of the heart. The crew have been enjoying some island hospitality, but many are now refusing to leave. They have fallen in love with the sons and daughters of the local king. Perhaps he can be convinced to allow them to come with you? You can attempt to come to an arrangement, or else wait for him to consult his copper oracle.
Offer a wedding gift

The king is not only surprised, but moved to tears by the romantic composers he hears via the gramophone. He insists on a grand banquet to celebrate the union of his children and your crew. Both traditional music and a few cranks of the new-fangled gramophone accompany the beautiful ceremony, and then its bon voyage!
Convince the king your crew's affection is genuine

The king is delighted to see his children wed. Delicate understanding of local custom and a smattering of their language allow a message of true love to be conveyed. The king evidently thinks his children in good hands. Feasting, and to the amusement of all, terrible dancing, follows. For his departing children, it shall be the longest, most fascinating honeymoon.

Something is lost in translation. Yet the king smiles benignly, as if your crew still have a chance to prove themselves. 'He suggests a great hunt,' says your diplomat, 'or else we may await arcane judgment.' His eyes flick to a copper oracle on a dais.
Capture the king a prize animal

The hunt goes quite well. Beautiful boars inhabit the woods, and though tricky to catch, are little trouble for your experts. Though the king will still not allow you to leave with his children, the feast of boar brings everyone together in the moment. The lovers understand this moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.

The hunt is not perfect. The crew show courage in pursuit of a tiger, which draws the king's admiration. Sadly, they cannot catch it, which leaves the king wondering if your men will be able to provide once married. Thus, he decides not to let his children leave. Some of your crew remain committed to staying behind, and it is with regret you must continue without them.

Your naive hunters fail the test. Forest deer are everywhere, and hunting them hardly seems a challenge. Had your so-named 'hunters' any respect for nature, they'd have realised the sacred deer were not what the king was after. Instead they gather them up greedily. The king makes it perfectly clear your expedition must move on. With heavy hearts, the sailors return to the ship.
Face the verdict of the copper oracle

The oracle predicts a reassuring fate for all. Those who wish to remain for love will live fulfilling lives, but the same shall be true for those still committed to your expedition. All parties feel a sense of peace. Your voyage shall continue without any resentment towards those it leaves behind.

The copper oracle is disappointingly undecided. The king cannot, in good faith, allow his children to leave to an uncertain destiny. His ultimatum is that your crew become part of his extensive family or else they must leave alone. Though understandable, it is nevertheless regrettable when some decide to stay behind.

The copper oracle predicts that your souls cannot be saved. With your crew rotten to the core, the king makes it clear there can be no union with his children, and that you are no longer welcome. Heart-broken and bearing the burden of sin, the crew return to the triviality of duty.

The awkward gestures and diagrams in the sand prove highly offensive to the king and his people. Sensing outrage, the crew back away towards the ship. The angry locals fire arrows at their former amours. Fittingly, one is struck in the heart, and bleeds out into the brine. The rest return lovelorn, to their dreary maps and compasses.
Await the verdict of the copper oracle

The copper oracle sees only purity in your crew's hearts. It predicts a bounteous future for the king's children, and so with tearful pride, he gives the couples his blessing. The traditional ceremony is both spiritually uplifting and wholesome.

The copper oracle reveals a little doubt in your crew's hearts. The king interprets that his children will only be happy if they remain on the island., and that some of your sailors are not in love, but merely infatuated. Still, you must lose the fine crew who have formed genuine bonds.

The copper oracle reveals great doubt in your crew's hearts. The king does not for a minute believe that your inconstant crew are as deep in love as they claim. If they cannot demonstrate otherwise, it might be better if your people left.
Try to convince the king your crew is worthy

Careful diplomacy has him thinking twice. Perhaps there is a way for the crew to prove themselves. A lean champion steps forward. Fighting him may impress the king, or else you can try and outhunt him.
Propose a contest of champions

You have your champions. One-by-one the suitors fight the king's champion. Those who prevail, it turns out, are permitted to take their lovers to sea. Some fail, but can at least drown their sorrows during the farewell celebration that follows.

It is not a pleasant sight for the faint of heart. Your best champion is put forward, and subsequently knocked about the head for the entirety of the contest. At the end a cloth is needed to conceal the disfigured face. The king expresses his condolences for your loss, but all is fair in love and war.
Propose a hunting competition

It is close but the king's champion is outfoxed. By sundown your best hunter has claimed six boars to their five. The king will still not allow you to leave with his children, but the feast of boar brings everyone together in one moment. The lovers understand a moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.

Lacking the skill, your hunters try to cheat. Without knowledge of the island's fauna, they decide to follow the king's hunters in the hope of poaching the animal they are tracking. But they are led a merry dance. Three days pass, and your champion is missing presumed dead. The crew have no choice but to depart, tail between their legs.

The king is offended by your insolence. Without a word he boards a boat and heads out to sea. Some foolishly follow, believing he can be reasoned with, but they have even less knowledge of local boats than local customs. Their bodies will be dredged from the reef as your tactless expedition struggles on.
Order the crew to leave at once

Paradise lost! The expedition may be back underway, but the mood is abject as the beautiful island becomes but painful memory. Too painful for one, who is discovered dead, it is said, by way of a broken heart.

The copper oracle proclaims your crew's hearts sinful and wicked. Arm-in-arm with their new-found amours, the sailors await some happy answer. But the moment the king's arm is raised, daggers unsheathe, plunging into the hearts of the would-be lovers. Speechless and unharmed, the rest are free to leave the island, pondering the grave cost of faithlessness.
Leave without the crew who've fallen in love

It is a significant blow. Any happiness the crew might feel at their comrades finding love is consumed by feelings of resentment. How could they have been so selfish? The expedition goes on, but those who are still a part must take on twice as much work.
Temple of the Monkey God

With water supplies so low, the sight of an island waterfall elicits a mighty cheer from the crew. But up close, high temple walls adorned with monkeys shield access to the water, and the temple entrance is obstructed by a crowd of devotees, deep in ritual.
Have [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] shed light on the meaning of the ritual

'Nothing to fear from this ritual,' beams the anthropologist, having consulted a bound volume entitled 'Creed of the Monkey God'. 'If I am correct, the devotees gather to disperse the malefic spirit of envy. It would be excellent form for us to join in.' At which remark, the crew begin to look a little hesitant.
Join the ritual

Sure enough, the ritual unfolds into a jolly dance. With the shaking of rainsticks, and gentle swaying must come broad smiles, for this is how the monkey himself defeated the spirit of envy. A feast of grouse and soursop follows, and [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] is presented a monkey-tooth amulet as a gift. Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.
Just ask to get some water

[AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] negotiates the much needed-water, through a lengthy exchange of sound and gesture, not all of which the crew can be certain is relevant. Having collected the water, the crew are content to leave the unanswered mysteries of the Temple of the Monkey God behind them.
Have the first mate convince the devotees to let you through

The first mate does enough to persuade the locals - with flamboyant intimations of the hands - that the crew should be allowed to pass. Once water has been collected from the waterfall, the crew are able to put the adventure behind them.

The first mate cannot make himself understood, despite employing the most outlandish gestures. The constant waving of the hands and legs unsettles the local people and there is suddenly an air of tension.
Have your men threaten them

The men seem slightly uneasy. Still they charge, and the locals do disperse, clearing the way to the waterfall. But long after the water is refilled, and the ship has sailed, the crew have nightmares in which vengeful monkeys bedevil them for defiling their sacred temple.

Before the sorry men can ready their weapons the devotees have attacked, and yet more rush from the undergrowth. The party desperately dashes for the ship, but several are skewered in a rain of javelins, each hilted with the howling visage of the Monkey God.
Stay calm, and offer them a deal instead
The locals look expectant.
Deal
The local people are spellbound by your offer. They invite you enthusiastically to join their ritual.
Join the ritual

The ritual unfolds into a jolly dance. With the shaking of rainsticks, and gentle swaying must come broad smiles, for this is how the temple's monkey god defeated the spirit of envy. A feast of grouse and soursop follows, and as a celebration of trade and friendship, a monkey-tooth amulet is given the men as a gift. Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.
Just ask to get some water

Water goes without saying, seems to be the message from the enterprising devotees, who aren't offended the crew won't participate, but seem now to want to resume their ritual. The crew return to the ship, leaving the unanswered mysteries of the Temple of the Monkey God behind them.
No Deal

The locals are at first interested, but the foremost of them, clad in monkey skins and wearing a linen monkey mask begins scolding his peers, violently knocking offers from their hands with a monkey-pommelled stick. All parties are now just as agitated as before.
Have your men threaten them

The men seem slightly uneasy. Still they charge, and the monkey-mask and his devotees do disperse, clearing the way to the waterfall. But after the water is refilled, and the ship sailed, one of the crew reports nightmares in which vengeful monkeys bedevil him for defiling the sacred temple.

Before the sorry men can ready their weapons monkey-mask has led an attack, and yet more devotees rush from the undergrowth. The men desperately dash for the ship, but several are skewered in a rain of javelins, each hilted with the howling visage of the Monkey God.
Have your men retreat to the ship

Your crew run fearfully from the temple where the devotees stand so firm. The monkey-masked one is heard uttering hard and undecipherable words that many of the crew later become convinced is a curse dooming the expedition.
Offer the devotees some goods in order to pass
Avoid the temple and find another route to the waterfall

The men succeed in finding an alternative route to the waterfall that is also satisfyingly swift. All are happy that they have managed to refill the water so efficiently, and without having to disturb the ritual at the monkey temple.
Your crew tries to find a different way, but it would seem the only option is to reach the high precipice from which the water cascades. The jungle is very dense, and there isn't a clear route up.
Search for a route to the waterfall source

After some scrabbling amid bristly vegetation, the tired crew finally get up to the water source and fill the barrels. The journey back down with the heavy burden is equally exhausting, and scarcely feels worth it.

The men lose their way terribly, becoming separated as they try to prove themselves in the ascent. A dreadful thud sends a squawk of birds from the trees - it is one of the crew, impaled upon a monkey-pommelled javelin. The rest flee for the ship, but few will make it that far.
Give up and return to the ship
'What a waste of all our time' bellows a vexed sailor, and he is not the only one. The word failure is becoming synonymous with this expedition.
Avoid the island altogether and return to the ship
The crew troop sourly back to the ship, disgruntled at being so near, yet so far from this much-needed water source.
Mysterious Artefacts

The discovery of several strange artefacts aboard spooks the crew. Tied to the rigging, bunks, boards, and even atop the captain's desk. A warning, a threat? And who put them there? Since the nearby island is uninhabited, it is sensible only to think the perpetrator must be aboard. The crew must know or have seen something last night!
Ask the anthropologist
Ask the crew who did this
Throw them overboard and move on.

'For good luck,' remarks the anthropologist, inspecting the spherical red dolls, 'for the setting of goals, and perseverance in achieving them. Some people or spirit of this place believe they can help us home.' At this, your crew are beguiled.

Your crew are beginning to bond. Someone comes forward, not having expected to cause such a bother. 'They're for me old mum,' he sighs, 'birds - that one's a little robin. Made 'em together when she was ill. Now she's gone...I...' The others are quick to put an arm round his shoulder; they're all in this together.

No one has anything to offer but the priest. It is his belief that some unholy chapter has opened. The next morning, more of the eerie things have appeared. 'Cleanse the idols in holy fire!' he shrieks. 'Nonsense,' says a soldier. "Set guards within, and we shall have this rat."

A destructive episode. No one has information, or perhaps they withhold it. Consensus tends towards the latter. Someone wants this expedition to fail, and these effigies are a threat. Paranoia festers. At the next port, a large part of the crew opts to quit.
Chilling. As instructed, the crew collect the dolls and throw them overboard. But relief lasts only until the following morning, when the dolls are found returned, placed exactly as they had been.
Side with the priest and prepare a holy fire
Keep guard and capture the perpetrator

The priest gloats over his success. With a maniacal grin, he sets the mound of idols alight. The fire consumes rapidly, shifting vermillion to viridian. Some say they hear the wood scream as it goes. 'Expurgation is God's work, and I am chosen.'

The fire is chaotic, and the buckets of water seem not to extinguish, but provoke. The flame leaps to the priest's cassock like spring-heeled jack, and as it sweeps up his back, he is heard to utter his last words, 'forgive me father, for I have sinned.'

The teenagers are remorseful. 'It was a jape, a piece o' trickery sirs, we regret t'were not received so.' The crew are forgiving - the youths merely wished to contain their homesickness - and call for just fifty strokes of the birch per bottom.

That night, dire musket-shot is heard. A dead boy on deck, local. A second is seen diving to blue. Next morning a rhythm comes from an armada of river boats, armed with guns. There island is inhabited, and they know what you have done.

The sun is solemn that morning. The bodies of the dead guards are borne to the hold for burial, but not here, upon this cursed rock. Who killed them none know but the sinister effigies. The expedition fumbles on.
Engage in battle.
Leave immediately.

One warning salvo is enough. The river boats cluster and slow. Though they lower their weapons and allow you to leave, the anger that your crime goes unpunished couldn't be more marked in their faces.

Your ship is a sitting duck. Your crew cannot man stations fast enough to fire or manoeuvre. Enemy boats surround your ship, before scaling its sides. The blood shed on both sides will stain this ship and expedition forever.
Once your ship is underway she is free. Nevertheless your adversaries are excellent shots, and do damage to the sails and aft. The crew will have to make repairs in the days that follow.

A traumatic escape. In the hurry to leave, your ship is spun broadside and exposed to gunfire. There are injuries, but none so deep as the sight of the dead boy's accomplice below. He weeps, and clutches one of the idols - a good luck charm.
The Mutiny

Clear skies, calm seas, and mutiny brewing among your sailors. The strain of the expedition, the rationing of supplies, the though of danger and the constant, unnerving lack of recognition: it doesn't take much to push the crew over the brink between obedience and its opposite. They unite behind the charisma of their chaplain and drift away from the authority of the first lieutenant.
Have the lieutenant meet the unofficial leader

The two men reach an understanding. The chaplain's demands are understandable, and the first lieutenant's limits are logical. Both agree on working to reach a better balance of power and supply repartition within the crew, and they leave satisfied with the encounter. A fair outcome for everyone.

The discussion reaches an end, somehow. The first mate doesn't listen to the chaplain and the chaplain doesn't hear the first mate. Their to-ing and fro-ing is exasperating even to their own allies. After an endless debate over meaningless details, the two men seem to reach an agreement and shake on it, ending the hostilities. In truth, the established innovations are nothing more than old measures with new faces: novelty, not change.

There is no trust to be found in the rebel's hearts. The chaplain refuses to meet your first lieutenant on the deck and invites him to join him in his own quarters instead: in short, in hostile territory.
Negotiate with the chaplain in his quarters

The lieutenant manages to reason with the chaplain. The officer comes to the ringleaders' quarters unarmed, and stands his ground while surrounded by nothing but hostile faces. He call to the faith of the chaplain and argues for a slow if deep change in the ship's line of command, offering his own position to the chaplain as long as he his kept as a close advisor. His stepping down is discouraging for the loyalists, but it was the only available option at this point.

The meeting goes nowhere. With each new compromise offered by the first lieutenant the chaplain adds an additional request, growing more and more assured of his dominance in the current stalemate. The officer leaves with a list of impossible demands and the ringleader's followers stop working altogether. The ship comes to a stop, waiting for a decision to be made.
Be subtle, send the chaplain poisoned wine

A swift and efficient assassination. Convinced of his advantage in the current situation, the chaplain gracefully accepts the first lieutenant's wine. The poison does not act immediately, but its effect is unequivocal: at dawn, the chaplain is bent over his desk, wide-eyed and grey as dust. No sailor dares to mention the reason for his death. Their caution enforces discipline, fear of their officers, and a general distrust of alcohol.

The poison is obvious. The wine reeks, its smell so deadly and its color so murky it might as well have a skull and bones drawn on its label. The chaplain forces the lieutenant's envoy to drink the whole mixture. As the poor girl quivers and coughs blood and bile, the ringleader and his followers leave their quarters - by the time the envoy is dead, they are standing before the first lieutenant's cabin, armed and set on killing.
In a final attempt at peaceful resolution, offer a bribe
This will be costly.
Okay

The bribe is enough, but its price goes beyond monetary value. The chaplain's despise for the first lieutenant spreads to the crew as they learn of the murder attempt, and the mob of sailors lock their officers in their cabins to stay there until the end of the trip. That they were not killed is the only victory the officers can enjoy.
Cancel

True anger can only be quelled with bribes of blood. The chaplain ignores the first lieutenant's plea. The man of faith pulls a rosary from his wrist, gestures for his men to act, and prays. With each bead which passes under his fingers a rebel plants his sword into the lieutenant, and as the officer screams so does the chaplain chants, louder and louder, until the prayer stops. When they leave the cabin, a new and mad order is established on the ship.
There is no choice but to confront them

Reinforcements come running at the lieutenant's call. The chaplain and his followers are surrounded and swiftly defeated, their strength no match for the loyalists' military training and devotion to their officers. Order is reinstated, the loyalists turned into a militia which reigns over the other sailors and suppresses any attempt at questioning the working conditions and power dynamics on the ship.

The loyalists are less prepared, less convinced, and more brittle. The rebels break them, destroying what few sailors still tried to uphold discipline on the ship. The chaplain has the survivors attached to the mainmast and forced to drink poison, letting their corpses rot where they stand - a display which warns all sailors against condemning his actions. The trip continues under the rule of the chaplain, with the crew convinced that they just replaced a tyrant with another.
Be clear, arrest the chaplain for high treason

The man of faith is captured and executed. The loyalists storm the chaplain's quarters and seize him before his followers can react - men used to fight with words can do little in the face of physical oppression. The chaplain is judged on the deck for all to see and hear, accused of high treason, then hanged on the mainmast and left to rot for a week. Fear keeps the sailors in check for the rest of the trip.

The arrest is a bloodbath. If the loyalists had had an advantage in discipline or numbers, the arrest could have been quick. However, the whole crew enters the melee, sailors hitting each other blindly, unsure which side they're attacking and which they belong to. The chaplain is dragged across the deck and hanged without trial: a display of gratuitous violence which brings the sailors back to their senses. The body of the man of faith oscillates in the wind, shredded and limp, mirroring the crew.
Be ambiguous, ignore the chaplain's demands

Inaction is not what the sailors hoped for. Both loyalists and rebels are dismayed by the absence of decision and restlessness spreads through the crew until the tension finally explodes: the first lieutenant is found dead in his quarters. The defiant act is not punished and most sailors interpret it as yet another sign of weakness, while others argue that the murder was judgment in and of itself.

The discussion is one-sided and disastrous. The first lieutenant barges in the chaplain's quarters and belches a series of commands, menacing the ringleader and his men of flogging, hanging, marooning and flogging again. The loyalists feel ashamed of following such a disrespectful idiot. Under the cover of the night, when the chaplain and his followers steal a long boat to desert the unbearable rule of the officers, many sailors follow. Less than half of the original crew remains.
That's enough disobedience, arrest the chaplain

The loyalists' strength dwindles when facing friends. Loyalists and troublemakers collide in a short and feeble brawl, each side unable to give up or to kill their former crewmates. Shots willingly miss, slashes willingly fumble, punches willingly go limp. The fight goes out without a clear victor, and the rest of the trip is spent with both side wary of each other.

The loyalists are too weak. The conflict erupts into an exchange of slurs, then blows, then gunshots. Men and women frantically try to kill sailors who were good friends and both first lieutenant and chaplain are no exceptions: the ring leader unexpectedly draw a sword and both men impale each other, their deaths signaling the end of the senseless fight. The crew collects its thoughts to mourn the man of Church for the efforts he put in for them.
Offer a rise to the chaplain
The chaplain looks expectantly.
Okay

A pragmatic solution. The amount offered to the chaplain to buy his obedience is enough for the man of faith to ignore the incongruity of the monetary negotiations. With the roots of their problem still present the crew remains unruly, but the bought leader makes sure to maintain their anger at the lowest levels.
Cancel

The offer does not match the chaplain's expectations. If his calmness is to be bought, the price should be enough for him to share with all the sailors he roused. The offended man of faith retreats to his quarters without a word.
Make an example out of the ring leader

The budding mutiny is easily crushed. The first lieutenant and two loyalists are all it takes to seize the chaplain and drag him to judgement: the man is condemned to be marooned on the next deserted island they find, and left to die at will or live in solitude. The swift arrest and punishment impresses the rest of the crew and renews their respect for their officers.

The loyalists' strength dwindles when facing friends. Loyalists and troublemakers collide in a short and feeble brawl, each side unable to give up or to kill their former crewmates. Shots willingly miss, slashes willingly fumble, punches willingly go limp. The fight goes out without a clear victor, and the rest of the trip is spent with both side wary of each other.

The loyalists are too weak. The conflict erupts into an exchange of slurs, then blows, then gunshots. Men and women frantically try to kill sailors who were good friends and both first lieutenant and chaplain are no exceptions: the man of faith unexpectedly draws a sword and both men impale each other, their deaths signaling the end of the senseless fight. The crew collects its thoughts to mourn the chaplain and the price he paid for them.
Ignore the discontent and let it wane

Inaction is not what the sailors hoped for. Both loyalists and rebels are dismayed by the absence of decision and restlessness spreads through the crew until the tension finally explodes: the first lieutenant is found dead in his quarters. The defiant act is not punished and most sailors interpret it as yet another sign of weakness, while others argue that the murder was judgment in and of itself.
The Predator

'A fearsome predator stalks us!' the cabin-boy whispers. Perhaps he is right, for this resupply has not been as uneventful as hoped. Only the first evening moored in this bay, and a man goes missing - tracks up the beach into jungle. Many wonder how work can be expected to continue...
Bait the creature

With the perfect lure placed enticingly in the crook of a tree, there is an inevitability about a capture. Sure enough, yellow eyes pierce the darkness, and a mighty beast pads softly over to the bait. A net is hurriedly cast about it and secured, thus leaving the expedition free to resupply unthreatened.
Send hunters to track it

Your huntmasters are expert, and trace with great care, the soft hollows imprinted by feline paw. Led to a clearing, they correctly judge this to be a lair, where they stand ready with a net. When the cat returns, heaving hot breath, the hunters pounce. With net secure, the expedition is free to resupply unthreatened.

At least one hunter did the right thing, and kept his eyes open while they traced the beast's pawprints. Another was not so wise, and was heard to let out a scream. His comrades were drawn to the spot, and struck the majestic beast down. But not before the damage was done.
Three days pass, and still no word. There is a common feeling something must be done to save those men.
Send a rescue party

It is only something of a relief when the rescue party return. It's bad news... the hunters are dead. The rescue party described the bright and long-maned beast, and how in a tussle, they slayed it. With the bodies of the hunters buried, the expedition is able to resupply in an atmosphere of respectful silence.

'Horror! It's picking us off one by one!' bawls a fearful sailor, for now the rescue party too, have failed to return. There is nothing for the disconsolate remainder of the crew to do, but leave this sorry place behind.
Wait a bit longer
Doubtful prayer brings no news of the lost hunters. The men have nowhere to look for guidance, and there is a burdensome feeling that a decision must be made.

Conviction in the lord is of little use here, it seems. Two days later a hunter, whose leg is mangled, limps back into view. After the necessary amputation, he is heard to groan that the others perished. All must leave this savage place.
Leave the island without them

'We leave them for dead, when they could be right there now waiting for us!' cries a furious old tar. Like so many others, he is disgusted that good men should give their lives for nothing but impatience!
Speak with locals

'Absurd magic, but it works!' say officers sent to the inland village for help. Having described the beast, they were referred to a witch. She encouraged them to ingest live scorpions, one of each colour; yellow, red and black. This they did reluctantly, but found when they confronted the animal, it took flight. All promptly follow the witch's advice, and sure enough, remain undisturbed for the remainder of the resupply.
'Our plight means nothing to the locals,' bemoan the officers sent as diplomats. 'Telling them beasts stalk the jungle, is as like alerting a hatter to the presence of hats on his hatstands.'
'Their deity is desecrated!' urges the officer sent as diplomat. All around the bay, daubed faces appear, bows raised to the expedition camp.
Teach them a lesson
'A hollow victory', say the men. For the locals lie dead, but the jungle beast stalks on.

Odds against them, the men fight as best they can. Fought back onto the sand, they deflect the rain of arrows with whatever they can lay hands on. A relay is able to return precious equipment to the ship and set sail, but not without a number of casualties, of whom some do not make it.

The onslaught is deadly. Few among your crew have the requisite experience to defend themselves, and so the sand reddens with their blood. Of those who make it as far as the expedition ship, a number succumb to the poison-tip arrows. It is a massacre.
Run for the ship!

'Run!' comes the panicked cry. The men drop their work, and tramp desperately through the shallows to the ship. A volley of arrows pierces three, squirting crimson into the clear blue. 'Dead aside, we have lost a great deal more in provisions than we have gained,' laments the quartermaster, as your ship departs that wretched bay.
Lay a trap

The ingenious powers of the craftsmen among your crew have fashioned a pitfall for the beast. There is not long to wait before there is a tinkle on the handbell, and all can gather above the trap to see the monster growling at its bottom. The resupply may now happily proceed, knowing that danger is averted.
The beast is too intelligent to fall for makeshift traps. It is clearly evading the pitfall prepared by those supposed to be the expedition's deftest craftsmen. 'Little more we can do,' they shrug.
Leave the island

'It's a considerable setback,' say senior officers. Fresh water, wood for burning, plants for medicine - it does no good to list what myriad opportunities are missed in bypassing the bay. And all for the sake of fears over one measly wild animal.
A Grizzly Encounter

Bear attack! The party ponder this very real possibility as threatening grunts stop them dead among the firs. Fifty yards ahead, a huge specimen lurches up on two legs like a totem, standing between them and escape. More grunting echoes nearby. The party stay silent, awaiting guidance.
Scare the bears away
Boooooom! The valley shudders with the sweet stench of exploded dynamite. The bears hurry away, leaving the crew thoroughly entertained at the superiority of mankind and the power of invention.
Use hunting knowledge to get the better of the bears

Trust in the expert hunters never feels misplaced, even when they recommend the party break into passionate song. For singing the shanty 'Cheerly-ay-oh' brings the crew together, whilst also dispersing the wary bears deep into the forest.

The hunters lack guile. They have enough to lead the crew on a route silent as a church, but not enough to stop a bear sniffing them out. It's easy to believe from its vacant eyes, that it sees you as a potentially delicious kind of threat.
Attack the bear

The bear's face proves a good target. Ducking the terrifying whooshes of its paws, someone manages to prime their pistol and shoot it through the eye. The bear drops dead. No-one feels particularly good about killing it, but the way ahead is now clear.

Adaptation is good when a fight isn't going well. The bear flinches but does not drop after the first round of gunfire. There is no time to reload, before it is upon them with its paws. Knocked down the men are smart enough to play dead. After an hour or so facing the floor, the bears lose interest and leave. The crew are able to lick their wounds, and move on.

It's easy to underestimate mummy bears. As the soldiers fluff the loading of their weapons, the bear nonchalantly grasps one by the wrist, and sinks her jaw into his neck. The others panic and flee with their arms in the air. She pursues a second, striking him dead against a rock. Now she and her cubs can finally be left in peace.
Outmanoeuvre the bear

Sometimes it helps to know your hill contours. The crew carefully fall away, circumventing the bear's position, and keeping their backs to the mountainside. With the higher ground, the bear appears to lose interest. Hearts pumping, the crew hurry to safety.

Stupidly the crew decide to run, and reach a dead-end. The bear pursues at a leisurely speed, yet with no less menace, and the crew are forced to seek refuge in a cave, or else try climbing the trees.
Hide in the cave and pray

Against all anxiety, the Bear doesn't follow. Still, the men in the cave are too afraid to light a fire, or sleep through the night. Shattered and hungry, they emerge the next morning, only to find their sacrifice was wholly unnecessary.

Bears can see terribly well in the dark, and since your crew have stumbled into its house, where its vulnerable infants sleep, it is not very happy. The crew that do manage to break for daylight have clothes ragged and torn, and cannot speak, for it is clear they were the lucky ones.
Climb the trees

The crew climb the trees well enough, but the bear isn't going to make their lives easy. It is a full day and night before it gives up shaking trunks, or climbing halfway up towards the dangling crew. When it finally leaves, the exhausted crew descend, their nerves in shreds.

Bears are awfully good at climbing trees, and as on this occasion, it is not uncommon to see them strike their adversaries from the branches. Its hapless victim plunges from the canopy and lands like a sack of red berries on rocks below. Others injure themselves as the men drop from the trees in a desperate escape.

Call themselves hunters! The tracks thought to lead away from bear territory go instead to a clearing at its heart. The bears at first seem alarmed their picnic is disturbed, until they realise your crew are on the menu. The sound of crunching bone rings in the ears of the few that manage to flee.
Attack the bear blocking the way

The lone bear's haunch is picked out with expert marksmanship. It staggers before bounding off into the woods. Your crew are delighted to return to the safety of the ship, whilst also having done the mighty beast no lasting harm.

The first volley of shots miss, and the bear attacks. A second shot finds its mark, and the wounded bear escapes into the trees, but a man lies dead. His brother cries revenge, and is already off into the woods to hunt the grisly killer.
Track the wounded bear with him

Bittersweet. Your fine tracking skills allow the crew to catch up with the bear and watch it from hiding. It is a she-bear, and is now nuzzling its young cubs. 'That is why she killed him,' says the brother, gone all vitriol. 'Let us leave, and hope my brother's spirit may somehow live on in this place.'

The hot-headed hunt is a success none celebrate. Once found, the bear no longer has strength to defend itself. As the brother drives a stake into its heart, it gives over with a last sad sigh. In that moment a tiny cub pads into the open, crawling weakly under the limp arm of its mother. If only they had understood, the crew could have saved the heartache.

Hunting is impossible with passions running this high. When another man snaps a twig, the vengeful brother attacks him wildly, and the others fail to intervene. The brother's eyes glaze as he slides to the earth, bayonet in his back.
Leave the fool behind

The decision is unpopular. 'Stubborn 'til the end,' say those in the minority. But the greater part have things to say on the subject of dishonour. 'Those brothers loved each other to the end,' remarks one old sailor, 'and what little love did we show for them...'

Out here, bears rule. The wildly inaccurate gunfire serves only to rile the bear into a frenzy, and draw attention to your position. Then a second, larger bear thunders from the undergrowth and mauls a man to death. A few of your piffling soldiery manage to escape with all their limbs attached.
Use Camouflage

The bears have no chance. Indeed, the camouflage is so good, the crew can barely see one another! Thickly daubed in the colours of the forest, the chameleon crew bypass the bears with ease. A story of ingenuity at which their grandchildren shall marvel!

Even the most hardened sailors find the smell unbearable. Not to mention the indignity of covering oneself in bear excrement for longer than is perfectly necessary. Eventually though the bears depart, leaving the reeking crew free to have a much-needed wash.

Dressing as pantomime trees is a bad idea, and as the bears attack, the flimsy branches the crew intended to cover their faces prove no more effective in self-defence. The ensuing scene might have made for an impressive spectacle on the stage, though only as the most gruesome of tragedies.
Of Unsound Mind

The man spasms, eyes rolling, before finally falling unconscious. His mania had come suddenly, with eight men needed to pacify, and bind him to the mast. Some say he is possessed by daemons and must be done rid of. The officers, less credulous, seek a surer explanation. The only way to silence a worsening quarrel, is to find a solution.
Enlist the aid of the hypnotist

The crew are delighted the man has returned to his normal self. The hypnotist used a pendulum to induce him into deep sleep, before imparting subliminally, some choice words. Within days the fellow is happily back at work. All are buoyant that such a severe case was so artfully cured!
Examine the cause of this wildness in him

It is a superb recovery in the circumstances. The examination uncovers a bluish contusion under the hair. 'We are to act swiftly or he shall die!' says the doctor, as he bores a drill into the man's cranium. Once the blood is drained, the resultant hole is covered with a silver coin, and the head beswaddled with bandages. The man is fully recovered within a few days, and the crew greatly impressed by the actions of the doctor.

The whole examination takes too long, 'though a bluish contusion is found under the hair. 'I must act or he shall soon die!' gulps the doctor, but then proceeds to faff nervously through a medicine bag, until the poor man dies on the operating table. 'You did the best you could,' a colleague offers, but there is a hollowness to it.

The patient grabs the doctor's head and smashes it against the table. The doctor was tapping his knee to check reflex, when the devil cut loose. 'He wants putting out of his misery,' a sailor cries, once the man is wrestled to the deck again. So they cut his throat. Attention turns to the doctor, but he is a doctor no more. Injury has rendered him insensible; an eight-year-old boy trapped in the body of a man!

Hellish horror ensues, as the doctor insists on checking if 'ought is stuck in the throat'. As he prises open the lion's jaws, the daemon creature lurches up into his throat. So frenzied is this vampiric assault, that there is little the crew can do but to raise their pistols to the gruesomeness. When the gunsmoke clears, doctor and patient lie dead, entwined and contorted beneath a bloody dew.
Try to calm the crew, and pray the man recovers

The crew are convinced by the chaplain that god has a plan for this man. They agree to bind him to his bed while the chaplain prays for his fast recovery. After two weeks he still suffers gaps in his memory, and a paralysis of the face, but thanks are given to the lord above that he is otherwise his usual self.

The sailors are partially convinced there is a spiritual explanation for his deranged behaviour, but insist on chaining him to his bed. 'He must have done something terrible in the eyes of God,' they say. Despite all hope for his fast recovery, he dies not two days later, his malady forever a mystery.

The faithless crew will not trust this to God, but can neither agree if the possessed man should be thrown to sea, as desired by the sailors, or permitted a chance to see out his ordeal, as demanded by the officers.
Side with the officers and warn the sailors to cooperate or suffer the consequences

The sailors would not dare mutiny, of course, and return to their stations. At first they fear the bed-ridden man will commit some terrible act while they sleep. But they need not have worried, since he dies of the unexplained malady not two days later.

The sailors are outraged and their response is immediate. In greater numbers they overwhelm and restrain the officers, while the sickly subject of their fury is bound and thrown into the deep. Confidence in the leadership of the expedition is undermined and the possibility of further trouble seems never far away.
Convince the officers the needs of the many must prevail over the needs of the few

No officer can deny the logic of the argument, yet, when the man is bound and thrown overboard they cannot help but show their grief it is for no fault of his own, and that none had knowledge with which to better help him.

'It's a bally disgrace! You dishonour a gentleman!' say the officers, as the man is bound and thrown overboard, 'such incompetence shall be reported to the highest authority!' Not only is a man lost, but the expedition brought into disrepute.
Guard him round the clock in his cabin

There was little for the guards to report, but occasionally 'quelling the mad dog' with liquor. After a fortnight, the poor man recovers with no recollection of anything, and while his hand is partially paralysed, he is still able to perform his usual duties.

The damn guards are found with sacks over their heads. They swear they did not see their attacker, but weakly-tied hands suggest collusion. Of course the patient's bed is vacant, and he seems to be missing, permanently. After that, rumours circulate, and no-one seems to have any trust in anyone else.
Ignore the officers and get rid of him before it's too late

The officers react with disgust to your decision to toss him overboard, and state in no uncertain terms that the whole matter will be reported. But the sailors are quite obviously relieved that his demonic presence has been exorcised.
The Seven-Year Itch

The crew are beset by insatiable and painful itching! From lieutenants down to pigeon-keepers, they twist and turn in their bunks and cannot sleep. It is affecting their capacity to carry out the most basic duties, something must be done!
Wash more often!

Washing a splendid idea at sea? Who knew?! The itching is very soon forgotten, as the sailors cavort through rainbows of expurgating bubbles. The rich perfume below deck is a welcome reminder of family and bygone days.
Analyse the symptoms

'Only jellyfish!' says the cultivated doctor cheerfully. 'Our refreshing swim at that cove appears to be the cause. It must have been rife with their larvae!' The crew marvel at the clever diagnosis, and as the itching subsides, bask in the pioneering case-study they have performed for the benefit of humankind.
The red welts seem to perplex the doctor. 'There is evidence of the parasitic,' he splutters as he peers through his magnifying glass, 'but then it could be nothing at all!'
Examine the cabins for some sort of parasite
There are bedbugs everywhere! There must be something that can be done to exterminate these disc-bodied hangers-on!
Refurbish the cabins

The matter is craftily 'put-to-bed'. Despite the time-consuming upheaval, the crew are surprised to have their cabins so well refurbished. 'They're too soft on us,' says a jolly cove inspecting the new bunks, but my britches haven't itched all day.'

What dreary decor!' says the Lieutenant tartly. Matters deteriorate when some ill-fashioned bunks collapse. 'I'd rather have the itching back,' says an exhausted-looking sailor. Like others, he has to sleep out on the hard decking, until some competent craftsmen can come aboard.
Simply change the sheets

It is a job half-done. For most the problem goes away, but some must live with the itching. Wherever the bugs' nasty little hidey-hole is, it must still reel with lousy punters, each telling stories of the sailor blood they drained the night before.

They cannot see the wood for the trees! Evidence of fleas would be everywhere to the right pair of eyes. Two weeks pass, and murine typhus breaks out. Rashes, fever and vomiting grip the fleas' hosts, who are never able to find the cause of their itching agony.
Have the afflicted bathe in holy water

The priest's most divine bottle does the trick. 'This water is indeed holy!' he says, as the fearsome muscovite vodka from 1791 is uncorked and slapped over the itches of the queuing sailors. 'Shame to use it like this, but I'd rather sleep,' he cackles.

'Is nothing sacred anymore?' Says the priest, who turns up his nose at the suggestion of using his water for something so humdrum. 'The lord hath bigger fish to fry,' he says pointedly. As well as the vile and incessant itching, the crew now have a parsimonious priest to contend with.

The doctor is a demented quack. When the condition is established correctly as crusted scabies - contagious, but hardly dangerous - the doctor's experiment is for the affected to bathe in an acid solution. Needless to say, his victims do not survive their injuries. When the expedition returns, it is entirely possible he may be stripped of his profession.
Find somewhere to stop and be rid of it

Sand and sun is a panacea! An acute sense of direction leads the ship to an island paradise. A freshwater lagoon relieves the itching, and the much-needed relaxation will stand all in good stead for the journey ahead.

Bringing contagion to port might be a bad idea. The itching is at its worst by the time the expedition reaches the bustling alien seaport, something the local authorities don't fail to notice. The harbour-master's tug escorts you to quarantine. How do you escape?
Lie that the sickness isn't contagious

The lie works like a charm. A doctor promptly comes aboard to confirm this hypothesis. Although she sternly points out the condition is contagious after all, she also recognises it to be a mild complaint. 'Crabs,' the translator says, face flushing. The crew are too relieved to feel embarrassed.
It is obvious you are lying, and the authorities are not impressed. They allow several days to pass, without any word on your ship's release.
Threaten them into letting you go

They don't want any trouble. A doctor comes aboard ship and goes nervously about his business. Although the atmosphere is somewhat cagey, medicines for your crew's skin conditions are provided, and the expedition can continue on its way.

You underestimate them. Two surprise warships hove round the landspit and close in to firing range. There is no choice but to run. As your ship crashes wildly out between jetties, the escort ship pincers, and opens fire. The effect is catastrophic. Your modest vessel flees in tatters, and many good sailors are dead or wounded. For the rest, the itching is set to continue.
Await quarantine

It's a long time before the authorities deal with you, with bureaucracy seemingly a way of life here. When you finally have access to a medical professional, there is already a post-mortem to be conducted. It appears chemicals leeched into the water supply and caused the rashes and sickness. With the water changed, the others recover, but it cannot redeem the loss of a life.

It's impossible for your aimless navigators to concentrate. The expedition fidgets wildly off course, with no land in sight. Meanwhile the assassin bugs continue to spread their dreadful disease. Even they'd probably make better navigators! Then there wouldn't have to be quite so much death!
Let them itch, it's common at sea

It is a particularly awful itch however. The disgusting lice infesting the ship, and discomfort thereof has many questioning the worth of your expedition. There is only so much scratching a crew can take before they lose all appetite for the journey ahead.
Parasitic Infestation
These parasites must have come from the marsh goo; all that waist-high wading. Now they nestle deep in your crew, who, at risk of harm from their own madcap cures, really need professional help!
Bathe them in alcohol
Treat the afflicted
Hope the problem goes away.

A delectable disinfectant! The suffering take immense pleasure scouring themselves in a whacking great tub of the stuff. Indeed, so diverting is this new form of alcohol absorption, that even those without parasites take turns.

The doctor concocts a panacea, which not only purges the belly-dwelling roundworm, but more besides. Garlic, wormwood, and lemon quietly see off a myriad other complaints of your spoon-dodging sailors.
The doctors disagree. 'Madam! Bloodletting gives our patients only a fifty-fifty chance!' says one. 'Sir, tinctures are seldom beneficial OR effective on parasites!' says the other.
It does go away, eventually. 'My arm looked like a wormcake for a while,' one sailor laments, 'but that little smattering of holes filled-up with pus now - signs my body is winning the war.'
Mass amputation for all?! The festering parasites have gnawed their way to bone! Limbs must be chopped, or else their bodies shall rattle with bemaggoted cavities!
Try the latest tincture
Risk bloodletting the patients
Let nature take its course
A fine placebo. As if by magic, the intestinal worms lose the will to go on. The doctor freely admits this is more likely down to positive patient attitude, than his revolting tincture.

The unpleasant medicine doesn't help. Constant trips to the privy are now the only release for your bug-ridden crew. The doctor admits to the failure of the tincture, but thankfully has something for diarrhoea.
The tincture is poison! Having seen their first shipmate choke on his dose, the rest decide they'd rather live with a six-foot tapeworm in their bellies.
Somehow it works, and the patients are rid of the parasite. The doctor seems unsurprised, 'human physiology may be complex, but treatment need not be.' A pretty vague case summary, but who cares?!

Perfect preparation for amputation! At least that's what your crazed doctor would have you believe... Once her macabre experiment is concluded there is surely only one course of action for the afflicted...
It does go away, eventually. 'My arm looked like a wormcake for a while,' one sailor laments, 'but that little smattering of holes filled-up with pus now - signs my body is winning the war.'
Mass amputation for all?! The festering parasites have gnawed their way to bone! Limbs must be chopped, or else their bodies shall rattle with bemaggoted cavities!
Have the doctor amputate
Let nature take its course
As good as could be expected. Out with parasites, in with polished peg legs and helpful hook-hands. The crew look not nearly as enthusiastic as you might think however.

Extraordinary that you trusted that quack! She is sideshow surgeon, carving up her victims with the zeal of a ripper, and the accuracy of a pissing schoolboy. At least the screams will die away soon enough...
Nothing can save them. Though a mercy that they may choose their manner of death - unmolested by the ship's quack - it is death nonetheless. The parasite has sucked the life from your expedition.
Cut or Lift

Sailor under the mast! Weeks of harsh weather have taken their toll on the ship and the violent gusts of wind of this morning have toppled the mizzenmast. For a moment the ropes tying it to the other masts hold it in place, but there is only so much weight they can take: they break with a snap, letting the mizzenmast plummet on the deck. A sailor now wails, his leg caught under a pole twice his size.
Cover the leg with a mix of water and soap and pull it away

The sailor is easily pulled from under the mast. The foamy water allows the crushed leg to slither away from the debris and the limb emerges covered in rainbow bubbles and bloody splinters. The man will live and maybe, with a miracle or two, his leg will mend.
Cut the leg with a bone saw

An extreme but recommendable choice. The sailor is given rum to drink and cloth to bite before he is held in place, his leg bound with a tight tourniquet. The doctor's labour is gruesome and the man can feel the grinding cuts as they tear through him, and he screams through the cloth and he howls and he roars - and yet the doctor stays composed and focused. When the leg is finally cut and the sailor dragged away, the crew feels that they are in capable hands.

Butchery. The doctor's hands tremble more than his victim does, and the saw draws zigzags in the flesh, each cut unable to connect with the previous ones. The trapped sailor's screams become whimpers, then silence. The doctor has to be stopped before he can ruin any more of the unfortunate corpse, and his blood-clad figure sends a warning to whoever might ever need his help in the future.
Lift the mast with a makeshift lever

The man is freed. Using one of the partners broken by the mast, the crew fits the sturdy pieces of timber between the deck and the fallen mast, adding plank after plank in the opening and gradually raising the mast with ropes and pulleys tied to the mainmast. They manage to lift the mast long enough to free the sailor, and the doctor immediately tends to his crushed leg.

The vague idea of a lever never becomes real. The sailors try to lift the mizzenmast by rolling logs underneath, but the huge wooden pole is far too heavy for its rolling movement to be controlled. The mast lurches forward and rolls from the sailor's leg to his chest, pushing his insides out. The view stays with the sailors for days before they can finally reach a decent harbour, get rid of the broken mast, and clean up the grisly mess underneath.
The Inspector

'I do hope you've nothing to hide?' smirks the Royal Inspector, as his soldiers help him aboard from the row boat. Sailors twitch. Your ship is certain to contravene her majesty's law, since it has encroached into demilitarised waters.
Show the Inspector a Royal Permit

'Very good', grimaces the Royal Inspector, scarcely concealing his displeasure at having to let you off the hook. His remonstrations with his soldiers as he wobbles aboard the row boat are a great source of amusement for the crew in days to come.
Threaten him and his soldiers

The Inspector's lip wobbles. 'I beg you,' he says, 'I have a gift, if only you will spare us.' Sure enough, the gift is brought aboard as promised. But it is only once the Inspector and his soldiers are gone, that it feels safe enough to inspect the new acquisition.

The Inspector's face pales as he eyes the tigerish crew. He bows, and takes a half-step backward - a signal for his soldiers to disembark with him. Once gone, the crew breathe a great sigh of relief, knowing it to have been a close shave.
'This is far from over!' the Inspector snarls as he evacuates his men to the row boat. Sure enough, back aboard the royal clipper, he is seen making preparations to attack.
Set sail and try to outrun them
Slippery as an eel, steady navigation keeps your ship on the windward side, just out of the Inspector's clutches. After a tense pursuit he is forced to give up, to the crew's great relief.
Though the ungainly clipper is outmanoeuvred, the expedition is now many miles off course, and your ship's exhausted navigators must summon all their remaining stamina to get things back on track.

It's upsetting that the Inspector's clipper is near out of sight, when a hopeful last shot finds its mark, crashing in the main deck of your ship, and killing a luckless sailor. Despite having escaped, the crew are rattled by such ill luck.
Complete confusion among the navigators makes your ship a sitting duck, and the Inspector's clipper gleefully riddles it with cannonfire. Many die or are wounded, and the ship is left in shreds.
Sink the toad!

The last they expect is a quick counter. Surprised and windless, they're an easy mark. Your cannons flog the Inspector's clipper without reply, and before long, it is bubbling to the depths. The relieved crew scout the flotsam for spoils.

Though the royal clipper has it worse, it also deals significant damage to your ship in the chaotic exchange. With casualties and repairs on both sides, the ships agree to part, so that they may lick their wounds.

The speed and power of the royal clipper is impossible to match despite best efforts. Your ship takes significant damage, and a young sailor is killed by shrapnel. Retreat is the only option. Mercifully the Inspector chooses not to make pursuit.

The superior clipper chews through your ship with its dread bank of cannons - the ruthless Inspector intent on bringing traitors to their knees. 'We surrender!' the crew cry, but the plea falls on deaf ears. Once he has shredded the ship to bits, the smug Inspector turns his clipper about, and disappears into the distance.

There is a commotion and the Inspector's soldiers are already among the crew. Being exceptionally well-drilled, they quickly force the crew to drop their weapons. 'Now,' says the Inspector, 'if you are quite finished, I'd like to continue my inspection of your vessel!'
Allow him to inspect the ship

'Though this appears to be a trade vessel,' the Inspector says, 'Combat was a consideration when these sails were fashioned - unacceptable in Her Majesty's seas. Unless…' he winks grotesquely, '...we can come to some arrangement?'
Trade with the Inspector (Bribe)
'Load these crates aboard the clipper! What are you waiting for?' he huffs to his men. When they are done, he smirks and offers the merest of bows, before sailing away with the plunder.
Take consequences

'You will remain here until they are dismantled...' trills the Inspector, '...those perverse modifications to your sails contravening sovereign law of the sea.' As the nit-picking Inspector leaves, it is clear an arduous refit is needed before your expedition will be allowed to continue.

'This is obviously a military vessel,' the Inspector says, 'in sovereign sea subject to the amnesty.' He toys with the gold button of his greatcoat. 'There will be severe consequences, unless... I hope you don't intend to offer me a bribe?'
Trade with the Inspector (Bribe)
Take consequences

'I don't know what you were thinking, bringing an armed ship into these peaceful waters,' he says, 'but I take great pleasure in imposing upon you. the longest possible route around.' Once the Inspector has gone, the crew look to one another in dismay.

A disastrous melee ensues, in which the crew do not acquit themselves well. Some are skewered, the rest disarmed. The Inspector calls three captive sailors forward. 'Hang these men,' he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.

A disastrous melee ensues, in which the crew do not acquit themselves well. Some are skewered, the rest disarmed. The Inspector picks out the captive specialist. 'Hang this traitor,' he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
Talk him out of the inspection

"Rather excellent company", says the Inspector over a glass of port, "I've been dying for something to break the tedium of the sea." Surprising even his own soldiers, the Inspector demands a gift be brought over from the clipper to mark the occasion. Of course, when he finally leaves, the crew collapse about in relief.

'Very well,' says the Inspector, after being given the first mate's 'special tour' of nothing in particular. He silently surveys the vessel for a torturous moment, before declaring 'it all seems above board.' Of course, as soon as he and his soldiers have disembarked, the crew of your ship collapse about in grievous relief.
'Save your breath, windbag,' says the Inspector, with an air of a man accustomed to weaselling. 'Show me the damn ship, or I shall become vexed!'

'You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,' the Inspector sneers, pointing to three unlucky sailors. 'Hang them,' he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.

'You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,' the Inspector sneers, and points at your specialist. 'Hang this traitor,' he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
The Trial

The crew faces the bloody customs of foreign lands. After a night of feasting, the sailors believe that meeting the foreign prince and his sea-traveling court is the highlight of their trip. However, morning comes with news of a sudden death among the court, and your crew is immediately accused of murder. The prince demands a trial by combat and your men are left with little freedom but the choice of the challenge's nature.
Send your strongest fighter for a brawl

What could a lord do against a sea-forged champion? The prince's warrior is nothing more than a scarecrow in shiny armor, and your own cotton-clad fighter scoffs at his tacky opponent. The walking wardrobe is tripped, grabbed, and thrown overboard in a single movement. As per foreign laws, your crew receives compensation and their name is cleared.

No word is brutal enough to describe your opponent. If his plate armor is scaled to match the man inside, then that man is a giant. The human mountain reaches to grab your fighter and crushes his skull like he would an apple. Word of your crew's feebleness and alleged crimes is sent for all cities to know and spread.
Send your best shot for a pistol duel

Your gunslinger shoots faster than his own shadow. His opponent drops to the ground before anyone can see or even understand that a gun has been fired, and only the banging sound and fuming barrel testify to the attack. The prince wonders how lucky your sharpshooter is, then reluctantly graces the crew and presents them with compensation for his offence.

Speed is not in your gunslinger's vocabulary. The prince's duelist, displaying the look of men who fill graves but never dig them, is the sharpest shooter your sailors have ever seen. Your best shot is dead before he even touches the handle of his gun. Judging his passing to be too low a price, the prince randomly selects men among your crew and has them hanged for good measure.
Send your brightest officer for a trial of wits

The foreigners are drawn in by your officer's pace. He inspects the body, noticing knife cuts of varying depths and bleeding. Through methodical questioning, the officer presses the foreigners and reveals the deception: each wound was made by a different hand, the victim was killed by all of them! The prince buys the sailors' silence and they leave wondering what could have motivated the curious murder.

A mute would have pleaded better. The officer engages in a battle of arguments with the prince's vizier, and each of his meager claims are met with factual evidence of their contrary. The prince cuts the exchange with exasperation and has the officer taken to be quartered till torn apart as a final judgement for the supposed crime. No scream ever matches the ones heard that day.
The Trial

These hoodlums are asking for it. To each harbour its own ill-famed tavern, and this one is no exception. While your crew enjoys a beer at the counter, the tavern's door slams open, the bartender stiffens and the volume of conversations dwindles: the newcomers are regulars of the bad kind. One of the scruffy men elbows your doctor and gasps as the alcohol splashes on his unkempt clothes. He immediately grabs your sailor by the collar and demands an apology.
They want to fight? Let them come!

Your crew crushes them. The collar-grabbed doctor slaps away the hand of the hoodlum, seizes his sleeve and pulls him above his shoulder, sending him to crash into a table. With a roar, the other thugs pounce on your sailors who greet them with jabs to the chin and sternum, downing the attackers with no more than two hits per man - the seconds for the pleasure of good fighting form. The tavern applauds the action and the bartender offers a round to celebrate the deserved beating.

The crew overestimated themselves. As he calls for the other sailors to help, the doctor gets his head smashed into the counter. His crewmates scream for revenge and look like toddlers agitating their little arms to try and hit the big bad guys. The thugs are not in the mood to play along, and one of them stabs a bawling sailor in the liver to make them shut up. They slowly die as the thugs depart, leaving the tavern in a stupor.
Offer them a drink to ease the tension

The language of alcohol is universal. The thugs take you up on your offer and eye the sailors' purses as they pass the money around to pay for the beers. As the first round arrives, one of the hoodlums speaks up and announces that they will have a drinking contest with the crew. The idea is one-sided and weirdly different from their previous aggressive attitude.
Show them the drinking ability of seafarers

They call that catpiss strong? There's no question regarding who wins the drinking contest: your crew is still standing and enjoying the beers long after the thugs have hit the ground, curled into whatever their stomach rejected. The pungent smell of vomit and cheap ale does not deter the sailors, who casually finish their steins, pay for them, and drag the hoodlums to the closest man of law.

What kind of liquid fire do they make this with? The crew is used to strong drinks and exotic ales, but the tavern's special mixture of bourbon, sugar and Ricard is way past what they can handle. The thugs are accustomed to this local horror and barely wobble while your sailors pass out one after the other. When they wake up, obviously, their purses are missing.
Drug their drinks to avoid the confrontation

War anaesthetics are remarkably useful against small-time thugs. After a few rounds spent boasting their virile resistance to any kind of liquor, the crew notices the drop in attention of their opponents and their doctor seizes the opportunity, lacing the incoming mugs with just the right dosage of chloroform. The snoring hoodlums are delivered to the local authorities, who enjoy the unexpected present.

The dosage doesn't put the thugs to sleep: it kills them. The doctor sidles among the thugs, lacing their drinks and snickering in expectation. Soon the effects appear: the gang shows drowsiness, then nausea, loses control of their movements and tumbles against the counter, their faces taking on a waxy yellow color. The crew can do nothing as the hoodlums break into seizures and foam at the mouth. They win the drinking contest by default, murderers of their opponents.

Bribing them with alcohol doesn't seem to work. Your crew invites the men to sit and share a beer, on them, to try and bring the tension down. The thug doesn't let go of the doctor and points at the aligned liquors behind the bartender. A glass of all of these, he says, and a bottle of your best whatever.
